results.title: The Impossible
results.creator_credit: Summit Entertainment, Apaches Entertainment, Canal+ España, Instituto de la Cinematografía y de las Artes Audiovisuales, Institut Valenciã de Cinematografia (IVAC), Mediaset España, La Trini, Generalitat Valenciana, Telecinco Cinema, Sparka Lee Hall, Álvaro Augustín, Belén Atienza, Ghislain Barrois, J. A. Bayona, Sergio G. Sánchez, Maria Reyes and Anna Bingemann
results.headline_credit: Spain and United States of America, 2012
results.brief_description: In December 2004, close-knit family Maria, Henry and their three sons begin their winter vacation in Thailand only for the devastating Indian Ocean tsunami to strike.

constellations_other.name: Representing disasters
constellations_other.description: The devastating Indian Ocean tsunami was captured by many people on personal devices and home cameras, with the footage broadcast to the world. The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Summit Entertainment, Apaches Entertainment, Canal+ España, Instituto de la Cinematografía y de las Artes Audiovisuales, Institut Valenciã de Cinematografia (IVAC), Mediaset España, La Trini, Generalitat Valenciana, Telecinco Cinema, Sparka Lee Hall, Álvaro Augustín, Belén Atienza, Ghislain Barrois, J. A. Bayona, Sergio G. Sánchez, Maria Reyes and Anna Bingemann
results.description: In December 2004, close-knit family Maria, Henry and their three sons begin their winter vacation in Thailand. But the day after Christmas, the idyllic holiday turns into an incomprehensible nightmare when a terrifying roar rises from the depths of the sea, followed by a wall of black water that devours everything in its path. Though Maria and her family face their darkest hour, unexpected displays of kindness and courage ameliorate their terror.
description_for_label: In December 2004, close-knit family Maria, Henry and their three sons begin their winter vacation in Thailand. But the day after Christmas, the idyllic holiday turns into an incomprehensible nightmare when a terrifying roar rises from the depths of the sea, followed by a wall of black water that devours everything in its path. Though Maria and her family face their darkest hour, unexpected displays of kindness and courage ameliorate their terror.

creators_primary.name: Instituto de la Cinematografía y de las Artes Audiovisuales

results.title: The Importance of making notes
results.brief_description: Discusses the important skills of note-taking, showing how to take good notes in oral instruction periods and during reading. Explains how to determine the key ideas for notes; describes the kinds of information which should be taken down verbatim, and points out when notes should not be taken at all.

results.title: The Importance of listening
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
If a discussion is to be useful it is essential to listen. The onus to keep the discussion going is on both the moderator and the participants. The moderator should: Summarise ideas and restore issues. The participants should: Listen to the other person’s ideas, acknowledge others’ ideas, question relevance. The case represented in this film is a discussion between black and white high school students and a white policeman concerning a fatal police shooting of a black man. The film uses this topic to illustrate skills of keeping a discussion on track (as a mediator) and relating participants’ comments and questions to each other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory

results.title: The Importance of keeping perfectly still
results.creator_credit: Michael Pattinson, Mark Ruse, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Kookaburra Productions
results.brief_description: Concerns a young man apprenticed to a high society photographer at the turn of the 19th century. When his boss receives a vice regal appointment to photograph the Governor’s family, he cannot handle the strain of this and a love affair at the same time. His girlfriend insists that she must have a ‘sign’ from heaven before a marriage can take place. Cast includes Liddy Clark, Frederick Parslow, Peter Sardi, Frank Thring, Frank Wilson.

results.title: The Importance of food safety
results.brief_description: This video is about how to safely handle and prepare food for public consumption. It is aimed at people who prepare food in the hospitality industry and other food handling professions, but contains useful tips to keep in mind when preparing food in the home. Discusses bacteria and how to lessen its effects, storage temperatures and conditions for food, both raw and cooked, freezing, thawing and cooking of food, delivery of food and how to lessen the likelihood of illness from improperly prepared food. Includes a questionnaire to test knowledge of content of video.

results.title: The Importance of flow in furrow irrigation
results.brief_description: Shows how the three aims of controlled irrigation can be achieved in furrow irrigation by putting the “correct flow” down the furrows so as to obtain even distribution of the water over the whole area and down to the depth of the root zone. The various factors which determine “correct flow” are briefly considered and finally the method whereby it may be obtained and checked is outlined.

results.title: The Importance of Equality
results.brief_description: A unique perspective on the Eureka Stockade story created by a Eureka 150 youth ambassador in a special Digital Storytelling Workshop to celebrate 150 years since the famous rebellion. This story made by Nosrat from Coburg shows how the principles fought for in the Eureka rebellion have resonance around the world today.

results.title: The Importance of being earnest [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Anthony Asquith, Teddy Baird, Two Cities Films, Javelin and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: Film adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s brilliant play “The Importance of being earnest” (1895), adapted and directed for the screen by Anthony Asquith, is probably the best-known comedy of manners in the world. Jack Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff are friends, both bachelors operating in English society hoping to find love in a proper match. Each man has spun lies about a fake identity in order to achieve romance with Gwendolyn Fairfax and Cecily Cardew, respectively. When the two couples meet up at Cecily’s place of residence, their lies unfurl and the true selves of both are revealed. Wilde’s last play is a satire on English society and manners, wonderfully sending up the portentousness and pomposity of the upper classes. Two particularly memorable characters are the boorish snob Lady Bracknell and the dithering governess Miss Prism (the latter played with import here by Margaret Rutherford). Asquith never quite transcends the script’s theatrical origins, but does successfully recreate the cadence and spirit of Wilde’s sardonic, barbed wit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony Asquith, Teddy Baird, Two Cities Films, Javelin and Rank Film Productions

results.title: The Importance of a good figure
results.brief_description: After an introduction to the computer, the film uses the processing of a railwayman’s pay to bring home the need for accuracy of computer input. Animation explains the technique which the computer uses to process staff pay. Examples of the wide use of computers show how more and more people are becoming involved with this need for accuracy.

results.title: The Impersonation
results.brief_description: Since it first became known in 1974, the signature of the contemporary English ‘primitive’ painter, Reginald Pepper, has been gaining prominence amongst critics and collectors. It now appears that such a painter does not exist. This film presents an overview of the case of Reginald Pepper and also looks at the broader issues concerning ‘primitivism’ in art.
